I watched these three videos back to back.  It was glorious to see a discussion that dealt with not just facts but things like "how to we define success?" "What do we mean by consensus?"  "What even is 'aging?'".

In south Africa we talk about skin care, especially in skin care cosmetic clinics, like lab Muffin does, we talk about delivery systems, skin tones, retinoids and  retinols. We have to give all the info through to our clients before we sell anything. We also have different ways to classify cosmitics, you have cosmectics, derma-ceuticals, end medical. Depending on your qualification and training in certain cosmetic houses, are you allowed to work with a certain class. For example only a fully internationally qualified somatologist may work with derma- ceuticals and the treatments that go with it, you may also work with medical but with a doctors supervision or as an assistant. South Africa has a few product houses that try to invest in medical studies to promote better quality products that you can only get from clinics. Some of these houses are in my opinion leading the way forward in the industry especially when it comes to dark skin. It would be good for you guys to have a look at some of these houses and ask them about their research.

Youtube suggested this video after I watched the original, but it was quite down on the list.  This video is a really nice continuation of the original and it'd be awesome if there would be a way for you to link them together (like pin a comment in the original linking to this).

me: awww thanks.

I'd be deeply skeptical of her advice. She's disturbingly unscientific and leans heavily on the fact that she's got a P.h.D. (in an unrelated field) which many people (who don't have the time or interest to research) interpret as "she's automatically right and all others are wrong."


In one of her videos, she makes a case against wearing sunscreen daily. In a long back and forth, I dismantled each of her arguments (while being highly deferential) and citing the research. 

The end result? She blocked me from her channel.


That's deeply problematic for someone who pretends to be a scientist since it shows a huge lack of scientific integrity. I can understand blocking trolls. But blocking people that respectively disagree with you... that is exactly how science works.

She also shows this scientific moral defect in situations where she makes highly clickbaity content on matters where X is good 99.9999% of the time. 

Her video will give viewers the impression that "it depends". While that's not an outright lie, it is highly deceitful. Again something that demonstrates a worrying lack of scientific integrity. Every domain of science (mathematics excluded) functions more like a Bayesian process where you judge something based on trade-offs, not absolutes. E.g. We advise people not to smoke, even though there may exist a person that somehow benefits from it because of some genetic mutation.


For those who might wonder about the aforementioned sunscreen issue, see research such as McKenzie & Lucas (2018) which states:


"If a sunscreen of SPF 30 was correctly applied on days with UVI > 3, but not applied on days with UVI < 3, over the course of a year, the cumulative dose to the skin on the low UVI days would exceed that from the high UVI days by a factor of 3.Thus, the messaging unnecessarily increases risks to health, such as the development of skin cancer. Advice that ‘no protection is required’ for UVI < 3 should be removed from public messaging. Furthermore, because skin damage depends on both the UVI and the time of exposure, that is the dose rather than the dose rate, behavioral messages should be further tailored to reflect the time needed, rather than having a simple binary message such as ‘protection required’ (for UVI ≥ 3) or ‘no protection required’ (for UVI < 3)."


Her comment sections may seem overwhelmingly positive (which is another worrisome point since many people use those to see if the OP is BSing/overlooking something), but that's not because there are no people who disagree, but rather because she blocks anyone who's anything less than a sycophant.

-Kelime-i Tevhid Nedir?
İslam dininin temeli, Kur'an-ı Kerîm'in en çok üzerinde durduğu en temel esası, Tarih boyunca bütün peygamberlerin uğrunda mücadele ettiği, Peygamber Efendimiz'in toplumlara 'kurtuluş reçetesi ' olarak gösterdiği Kelime-i Tevhidi Biliyor musunuz?

Kelime-i Tevhid '_La İlahe İllallah_' sözüdür. Müslümanlar olarak tevhidi sürekli zikrettiğimiz halde Allah'a hakiki manada kulluk yapamıyoruz ve hayatımızda büyük değişimler gerçekleşmiyor. Halbuki Peygamber Efendimiz Hz.Muhammed tevhidi anlattığında sahabe iman ediyor, şirk ve günah dolu hayatını bırakarak kendisine tertemiz bir sayfa açıyordu. "Allah'ın Dünyasında Allah'ın Dediği Olmalıdır." diyordu.

Hayatlara Tesir Eden Tevhidin Asıl Manası Nedir?

Yıllarca tevhid yanlış anlatıldı. Bu sözün manasının 'Allah vardır; Allah yaratandır' demek olduğu söylendi.Oysa Mekkeli müşrikler de 'Allah vardır; Allah yaratandır' diyorlardı. Kur'an-ı Kerîm onlar hakkında:"Andolsun onlara:Gökleri ve yeri kim yarattı, güneşi ve ayı sizin yararınıza kim boyun eğdirdi?'diye sorsan, 'Allah'dır derler" buyurur. (Ankebut,61) Peki o zaman Mekkeli müşriklerin reddettiği şey neydi?
İslam dini sadece 'Allah vardır;Allah birdir' demeyi iman olarak kabul etmedi. Peygamber Efendimiz(s.a.v),insanları sadece Allah'ın varlığına inanamaya değil Allah'tan başka bir ilahın olmadığını kabul etmeye davet etti. İşte Mekkeli müşriklerin kabul etmek istemediği de buydu. Tevhidin orijinal-gerçek gerçek manası 'Allah'tan başka ilah yoktur' demektir. Peki ilah ne demektir? İlah:ibadet edilen, kanun koyan, en çok sevilen demektir. O halde Müslüman olan biri'La ilahe illallah' derken 'Allah'tan başka ibadet edilecek, itaat edilecek yoktur; Allah'tan başka otorite, kanun koyucu yoktur;Allah'tan daha fazla sevilecek yoktur' demiş olmaktadırlar. Daha açık ifade etmek gerekirse bir Müslüman 'la ilahe illallah' derken şunları demiş olmaktadır: İşime gelen-gelmeyen her konuda Allah'ın dediği gibi yaşayacağım. Hayat programımı Allah belirler. Emretme ve yasaklama yetkisi O'nundur. Helal kılma ve haram kılma yetkisi O'na aittir. Hayata dair her işte O'nun hükmüne riayet edeceğim. Nasıl evleneceğimden, nasıl boşanacağıma, parayı nasıl kazanacağımdan, nasıl harcayacağıma Allah karışır. Neleri yiyip-yemeyeceğime ve nasıl giyineceğime Allah karışır. Devlet işlerinden sosyal hayata, kamusal alandan kişisel alana hükmedecek olan Allah'tır. İnsanların Allah'ın hükümlerine aykırı hüküm koyma yetkileri yoktur!''Çünkü Allah'tan başka ilah yoktur!''

Sunscreen!!! People assigned to daily SPF16 sunscreen use showed on average no change in visible skin aging grade over 4.5 years.

People who applied SPF30 every morning showed a REDUCTION in several signs of visible skin aging after 1 year.

Daily sunscreen has also been studied specifically in older East Asian people, and has been found to reduce the visible signs of aging around uneven pigmentation that Michelle mentioned.

Would love to see y'all do a video on year-round daily sunscreen.

sample size requirements are determined based on statistical power (i.e. 1 - beta), know effect sizes (or smallest effect size of interest), and measure reliability. What LabMuffin claims is misleading. When it comes to statistical inference, if your sample is too small then your analysis (i.e. parameter estimates) will be unreliable and unusable. The reason why small sample size papers ever get passed peer review is due mostly to either statistical illiteracy or other real-world constraints (e.g., the total population is that small).

Small sample size means low accuracy
wow great

You also are getting something wrong about sample sizes. Samples size does not equal consensus. Consensus has to be drawn from the interpretations of studies. And by the logic of teting for statistical significance, finding a. Significant effect despite small sample size, speaks to the effect size and it's robustness.
You can get get tiny, small effects to show up as statistically significant (which means, unlikely to be produced by chance) wirh a huge sample size. But this effect might be so small that the difference is negligable for all practical applications and real life uses. Gettung a significant effect to show with small sample size, means, yhat the effect is such, that you don't need lots of people to show that there is a systematic difference betweeen treatment group and control. So smal sample sizes can actually speak to the validity of tbe findings of a study.

I was glad y'all mentioned delivery systems. A big part of efficacy (or stability, at least) can be attributed to packaging, which I think a lot of people—skincare companies included—often overlook. For instance, putting a cream in a jar that requires you to open it up and expose it to the elements and dip your finger in it, can totally destroy the formula. That's why things like applicators or airless delivery systems exist. (Full disclosure, I worked for a skincare/cosmetics packaging company for 6 years.)
